column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-kerry-idUSKCN12R03X	To applause and boos
column2: Kerry urges Congress to ratify Pacific trade pact	"

column1: By Dave McKinney
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO Failure to approve the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal would be a major setback for U.S. interests in Asia as Washington seeks to deepen alliances in the region
column2: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday
column3: urging Congress to ratify the pact.The 12-nation Pan-Pacific trade deal championed by President Barack Obama has been pilloried by both major-party nominees in the U.S. presidential race
column4: Democrat Hilary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump.While Republicans have traditionally backed free trade deals
column5: Trump has blamed them for U.S. job losses and threatened to rip them up or renegotiate them if he wins the Nov. 8 election. ""If we see the TPP rejected
column6: it would be a gigantic self-inflicted wound - a setback to our own interests in the region
column7: Kerry told the Chicago Council on Global Affairs
column8: in remarks that drew a smattering of applause and boos.

column1: It would amount to a conscious turning of our backs on the Asia Pacific at the very moment that we ought to be linking arms - it would be an act that will hurt American workers
column2: slow our economy
column3: hinder our ability to advance the full range of U.S. objectives"" in the fast-growing region
column4: he added.Republican leaders have said there is no point in bringing the trade deal for a vote in the ""lame-duck"" session of Congress after the election.

column1: But Kerry urged Congress to approve the deal after the election
column2: saying: ""It's the right thing to do for America - and no matter what the loudest voices may be shouting - it is also the popular choice."" There are concerns in Washington that failure to pass the TPP would prompt Southeast Asian nations to turn to China and Russia.

column1: Kerry said the trade deal was a ""litmus"" test of Washington's capacity to lead and was necessary if the United States wanted a steady and reliable presence in the region.His comments came amid tensions with China over the disputed South China Sea
column2: increased concerns over North Korea's missile and nuclear weapons programs
column3: and questions over the future of the U.S.-Philippines alliance. (Reporting by Dave McKinney; Writing by Lesley Wroughton; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: MARKET OUTLOOK: ""The S&P 500 futures rose by 0.71 percent during the debate window in response to a 6 percent increase in Clinton's victory probability. This implies that market participants believe that the S&P 500 will be worth 12 percent more under a President Clinton. Movements in other U.S. stock indices tell a similar story. A 12 percent difference is large both in absolute terms
column2: and relative to how previous political shocks have moved the market."" MARKET VOLATILITY: ""During the debate
column3: futures tracking expected future U.S. stock market volatility fell sharply
column4: suggesting that markets are more uncertain about outcomes under a Trump presidency. Oil prices rose
column5: gold prices fell and Treasury prices declined slightly. Roughly speaking
column6: these movements suggest that a Clinton presidency is expected to lead to stock market volatility that is 15-30 percent lower
column7: Treasury yields that are 25 basis points higher
column8: and oil that is $4 per barrel more expensive."" GLOBAL MARKETS: ""Movements in overseas markets suggest that the U.S. election is expected to have significant global implications. The debate led the British FTSE 100 to rise by as much as U.S. stocks did. The same is true of many Asian markets

column10: which Trump has threatened to end or renegotiate -- rose sharply
column11: as did those of other nations with which the U.S. has free trade agreements... All told
column12: these movements suggest that financial markets expect a generally healthier domestic and international economy under a President Clinton than under a President Trump.""         (Compiled by Tenzin Pema and Geetha Panchaksharam in Bengaluru Newsroom; Editing by Dan Burns)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-lawsuit-idUSKCN12Q32L	Democrats ask judge to sanction Republicans over Trump	"
By Dan Levine

The Democratic National Committee on Wednesday asked a U.S. judge to hold the Republican National Committee in contempt of court over allegations that Donald Trump encouraged his supporters to intimidate minority voters.The DNC accused Republicans in a court filing of violating a longstanding consent decree
column2: which restricts Republicans' ability to question voters at the polls and prevent those people from casting a ballot. During the presidential campaign
column3: Republican nominee Trump has asked followers to ""watch"" for fraud in the Nov.8 presidential election in certain areas where minority voters reside
column4: even though no evidence of fraud exists
column5: the filing said. Some of Trump's followers have pledged to do just that
column6: the filing said.The RNC has supported Trump's ""ballot security endeavors
column7: Democrats said in the court filing.

column1: The RNC said the filing was completely meritless. ""The RNC strictly abides by the consent decree and does not take part directly or indirectly in any efforts to prevent or remedy vote fraud.  Nor do we coordinate with the Trump campaign or any other campaign or party organization in any efforts they may make in this area
column2: a RNC spokesperson said in an emailed statement. ""The RNC remains focused on getting out the vote.""Representatives for the Trump campaign could not immediately be reached for comment.

column1: The DNC asked a New Jersey federal judge to issue an injunction preventing the RNC from spending money on voter integrity efforts
column2: and to instruct its field offices that no employee shall participate in any ballot security measures.

column1: (Reporting by Dan Levine in San Francisco; Editing by Andrew Hay)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cuba-un-idUSKCN12Q259	U.S. abstains for first time on U.N. call for end to Cuba embargo	"
By Michelle Nichols
| UNITED NATIONS
UNITED NATIONS The United States on Wednesday abstained for the first time from a United Nations General Assembly vote on a resolution calling for an end to a U.S. economic embargo on Cuba
column2: after opposing such measures every year for 24 years.For the 25th time
column3: the 193-member General Assembly adopted the resolution with 191 votes in favor. Israel
column4: which opposed the resolution last year
column5: also abstained on Wednesday. Such resolutions are non-binding
column6: but can carry political weight.Communist-run Cuba and the United States
column7: former Cold War foes
column8: began normalizing relations in 2014. U.S. President Barack Obama has taken steps to ease trade and travel restrictions on Cuba
column9: but only the U.S. Congress can lift the full embargo.The Republican-controlled Congress has resisted Obama's call to lift Washington's economic embargo after more than 50 years. Republican critics say Obama is making too many concessions to Cuba for too little in return
column10: especially on human rights.The U.N. General Assembly applauded when U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Samantha Power announced prior to the vote that the United States would abstain.

column1: Abstaining on this resolution does not mean that the United States agrees with all of the policies and practices of the Cuban government. We do not
column2: Power told the General Assembly. ""We are profoundly concerned by the serious human rights violations that the Cuban government continues to commit with impunity against its own people
column3: she said.

column1: Cuba's Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez described the abstention as a ""positive step for the future of improving relations between the United States and Cuba.""Rodriguez said in September that damage from U.S. sanctions between April 2015 and March 2016 amounted to $4.6 billion and to $125.9 billion since the embargo's inception more than 50 years ago.In March
column2: Obama made the first visit to Havana by a U.S. president in 88 years. His trip was made possible by his breakthrough agreement with Cuban President Raul Castro in December 2014 to cast aside decades of hostility that began soon after Cuba's 1959 revolution.

column1: Since the opening
column2: Obama has repeatedly used his executive powers to relax trade and travel restrictions
column3: while pushing Cuba to accelerate market-style reforms and boost political and economic freedoms.The U.N. resolution adopted on Wednesday takes note of the steps taken by Obama as positive but ""still limited in scope."" It urges the United States to repeal or invalidate the embargo on Cuba as soon as possible. (Reporting by Michelle Nichols; Editing by James Dalgleish)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-senate-idUSKCN12Q2D3	Republicans may be on verge of losing U.S. Senate majority: aides	"

| WASHINGTON

column10: North Carolina and Missouri.A Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Wednesday and conducted from Oct. 20 to Oct. 24 found that 41 percent of Republicans now expect Clinton to win the election
column11: versus 40 percent for Trump.That is a sharp decline in confidence from last month
column12: when 58 percent of Republicans said they thought their party's nominee would win
column13: versus 23 percent for Clinton.Republicans now hold 54 of the Senate's 100 seats. Democrats must snatch four seats to win a majority
column16: beats Trump. That would make Clinton's running mate
column18: the tie-breaking Senate vote since the vice president votes in order to break a tie.

column9: who is trying to unseat Senator Roy Blunt

column2: this has been a volatile and unpredictable year
column3: and there is still time for trends to reverse. Democrats stressed they are not breaking out the champagne.According to RealClear Politics
column4: Toomey leads by 1.8 percentage points in Pennsylvania while Blunt is up by a point in strongly Republican Missouri and Senator Richard Burr has a 2.8-point lead in North Carolina over his Democratic challenger.Still

column1: Democratic President Barack Obama
column2: who is still relatively popular

column4: such as New Hampshire

Studies show a pattern of voting in recent decades in which the outcome of Senate races has had a significant correlation to who wins the White House.Polling in the hardest-fought states points to extremely close races with Republican incumbents' backs against the wall.In New Hampshire
column6: Republican incumbent Kelly Ayotte is in a tough race with her Democratic challenger
column7: Governor Maggie Hassan. University of New Hampshire political science professor Dante Scala said Republican senators in that state and Pennsylvania face the ""one-two punch"" of independent voters potentially being turned off by Trump and an electorate that leans Democratic in presidential election years like 2016.""Given the overall environment

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-banks-idUSKCN12Q2WA	Trump calls for '21st century' Glass-Steagall banking law	"
U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday called for a ""21st century"" version of the 1933 Glass-Steagall law that required the separation of commercial and investment banking
column2: a change the Republican Party also supported in its 2016 policy platform.Trump gave no details about his banking plan other than to say he would prioritize ""helping African American businesses get the credit they need."" Democrat Hillary Clinton's husband
column3: former president Bill Clinton
column4: signed legislation in 1999 that repealed Glass-Steagall.

column1: U.S. banking law was comprehensively revised by the Dodd Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act in 2010 as a response to the financial crisis of 2008.
(Reporting by Emily Stephenson)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-hollywood-idUSKCN12Q260	Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame star vandalized on video	"
By Alex Dobuzinskis and Omar Younis
| LOS ANGELES
LOS ANGELES Donald Trump's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame was defaced by a vandal wielding a sledgehammer and a pick-axe on Wednesday in an act captured on video
column2: police said.Los Angeles police expect to arrest someone for the vandalism
column3: which left Trump's name scratched out of the star
column4: the emblem in the middle dislodged and chips missing.     A video posted at Deadline.com
column5: a Hollywood media industry website
column6: showed a man wearing a hard-hat and reflective vest swinging a sledgehammer and pick-axe in the pre-dawn darkness.(To see the Deadline.com video
column7: click on this link: bit.ly/2dWGEdf )The area had been cordoned off with traffic barriers and cones
column8: giving it the appearance of a legitimate work site.The Republican presidential nominee
column9: real estate developer and reality TV star has faced several large protests during his campaign appearances in California
column10: where polls show him far behind Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.

column1: The former host of the NBC show ""The Apprentice
column2: Trump received his Walk of Fame star in 2007. A spokeswoman for Trump could not be reached for comment. Los Angeles police spokeswoman Liliana Preciado at the scene confirmed investigators have video capturing the vandalism attack and she said police expected to arrest whoever was responsible.Los Angeles-based City News Service reported a man identifying himself as James Lambert Otis said he damaged the installation ""to make a point.""

column1: City News reported the man said he had family members who were victims of sexual assault and had intended to remove the star
column2: which he was unable to do
column3: and auction it off to benefit women who have alleged Trump groped them. Trump has denied the allegations.Otis could not be reached for comment on the report.Trump drew widespread condemnations from voters and a number of Republican elected officials after a 2005 video emerged in which he was heard talking on an open microphone about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman.

column1: His star on the Walk of Fame was previously targeted.In the summer
column2: a street artist erected a tiny wall around the star
column3: complete with miniature American flags and barbed wire. The art piece
column4: which was later removed
column5: made light of Trump's campaign pledge to build a wall along the U.S. border with Mexico.The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce administers the hundreds of star plaques on sidewalks in the Los Angeles neighborhood. They are purchased for $30
column6: 000 each.Leron Gubler
column7: president and CEO of the chamber
column8: said in a statement the star would be covered for several days during repairs. (Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis; Editing by David Gregorio)"
